title: Public wi-fi a major cause of hacking, consumer affairs authorities warn
text:
The first time Perth man Casey Grogan, who runs a media and videography business from home, knew that he had a major issue with internet security was when a client contacted him about a strange email he'd received.

"I had a client who was in America at the time just hit me up on WhatsApp to say, 'Have your bank account details changed?'" Mr Grogan told Nadia Mitsopoulos on ABC Radio Perth.

His client told Mr Grogan he had received an email from his address, advising of a change of account details for payment of an invoice. But the tone had sounded off, prompting the client to contact Mr Grogan directly.

"He got the ball rolling, thank goodness," he said.

Mr Grogan quickly created a new email address and contacted his other clients to let them know, then discovered the hackers had been able to infiltrate that new address as well.

He has since engaged the services of an expert in combating hacking and discovered the cyber criminals had been right through his devices.

"They've accessed my Google account. They've known where I've been going. They've done Facebook, Instagram. They've deleted photos of passports, emails," he said.

" I'm unsure of what the future holds because I had a tech guy come over yesterday and he was telling me some stories of what they can do with all of this stuff. "

Shared wi-fi suspected

He did not know exactly how he got hacked but suspected it happened on a recent work trip to Victoria, when he noticed his laptop slowing down after he used the wi-fi in his hotel room.

"There's a massive problem, I found out, with any kind of public or hotel or airport wi-fi," he said.

WA Consumer Protection Commissioner Trish Blake said any kind of shared public wi-fi was known to be a huge vulnerability.

"If you are using free wi-fi at the airport, at your local fast-food takeout, in the mall or in a shopping centre, do nothing more than look at maps or search something on Google. That is it," Ms Blake said.

"Don't do emails and absolutely do not do your banking on those free wi-fi systems."

WA Consumer Protection Commissioner Trish Blake in the ABC Perth office. (ABC News: Cason Ho)

Ms Blake said the agency recorded a large spike in payment redirection scams after the pandemic led to many people working from home.

She said many professionals were working from cafes on the venues' free wi-fi.

"Those free wi-fis are deliberately open with very little protection around them because they're intended to be accessible by everybody in a big space," she said.

"We had a consumer who lost thousands of dollars after using a free wi-fi on a cruise. It is so simple for scammers to access it."

Extra layers of protection

She also recommended people use a virus protection service on their phone, just as they would with a home computer or laptop.

"Our computers are these little handheld devices that are in our pockets that we carry around with us everywhere," she said.

"Any virus protection that you can have for your computer or your laptop will also have a version that's available for your mobile phone.

"Get it from a reputable source. Do not use free virus protection."

Free public Wi-Fi should not be used for email or banking, consumer protection warns. (ABC News: Liam Phillips)

She said people also needed to get used to using multi-factor authentication on all their important apps, either through codes sent to the mobile phone or facial recognition.

"One thing that scammers cannot do is steal your face," she said.

"Take the time. Yes, it's annoying, but do it because being annoyed is far, far better than losing money."

She said Western Australia also offered an additional layer of identity protection through driver's license locking.

This can be done online and means that driver's license details, if stolen, cannot be used towards taking out credit or accessing bank accounts.

If a person is applying for credit or needs to use their ID for another reason, the license can be temporarily unlocked online then locked again to prevent hackers using it.

'It feels like a break-in'

While Mr Grogan was able to catch the hackers before much money was lost, the idea that they may have listened to his phone calls and looked at family photos on his phone left him feeling very disturbed.

"It's horrible. People spend a lot of money on home security, cameras and everything, because they don't want their TV stolen," he said.

"You can literally walk out onto the street with some basic viral virus stuff on your phone and your whole life can be turned upside down.

" It's so intrusive. It's like someone has walked into my bedroom at night, shirtless with a knife, just laughing at me. "

One of the first signs for Casey Brogan was his laptop computer suddenly slowing down. (Unsplash: Jay Wennington)

Trish Blake said it was important to remember that victims of cybercrime, while never in physical contact with their assailant, suffered an invasive event.

"It is absolutely a crime. You have been a victim of a crime," she said.

"Often my team spend a lot of time linking victims of scams into their GP and to counsellors because it takes a personal toll and it's a very normal reaction to this very invasive event."

title: ACT pharmacists set to be able to offer more treatment options
text:
The ACT government has announced it will expand the range of services Canberra pharmacists are allowed to provide.

The expanded services will include the administering of flu vaccines to children as young as two.

Pharmacists will also be able to treat for mild, acute musculoskeletal pain, gastro-oesophageal reflux disease, allergic and non-allergic rhinitis, acne, and acute nausea and vomiting.

The widening of these services follows a pilot program announced in 2024, which allowed pharmacists to treat uncomplicated urinary tract infections and resupply the oral contraceptive pill.

The changes will take effect from early 2026.

GPs 'aren't always supportive': minister

ACT Health Minister Rachel Stephen-Smith said the decision brings the territory into line with jurisdictions such as New South Wales.

"Pharmacists play a vital role in ensuring Canberrans are protected from influenza during the winter season, and these amendments will make it more convenient for families to get vaccinated next year," she said.

"We are, as health ministers ... interested in expanding scope of practice for all health professions because we know that we need our workforce to be working at the highest scope to take pressure off the specialists and the general practitioners."

Ms Stephen-Smith said pharmacists were "highly skilled professionals".

ACT Health Minister Rachel Stephen-Smith says they want to take pressure off the health system. (ABC News: Michael Barnett)

She said they would try to align as closely as possible with New South Wales, where similar changes had already taken place.

"And that means we can really build on the materials that they have, the training that they are establishing, but we're also working with the University of Canberra ... on training here," she said.

But not everyone is in support of the expansion, with the health minister describing the conversation with GPs about the changes as "challenging".

"They aren't always supportive — they certainly have not been supportive in relation to the urinary tract infection trial," she said.

"I think as more evidence comes in, those conversations might become a little easier.

"But one of the things I really want to reassure people [about] is this really an appropriate role for pharmacists is there is, for this expanded scope, a really significant training program involved."

Two-thirds of pharmacies expected to come on board

Pharmacy Guild ACT branch president Simon Blacker welcomed the move.

"[We're] certainly very pleased that the ACT government decided to go down that path, where ACT patients will be able to get the time and access to services as they need them," Mr Blacker said.

Pharmacy Guild ACT Branch president Simon Blacker says participants in the program will need to undertake "strong" training. (ABC News: Adam Kennedy)

He said pharmacists would now be able to more effectively treat certain conditions that they saw regularly.

"Something that we get asked a lot about is acute nausea and vomiting, and being able to give something that's prescription strength to treat that," he said.

"Ultimately, this is about patients in the ACT being able to hopefully stay out of emergency waiting rooms and free up GP appointments by chatting to their local pharmacist."

He said there was a "strong training program" that participants would need to undertake before being permitted to consult under the expanded rules.

Some in the ACT have already commenced that program, which runs for more than 12 months.

"And that gives safety and confidence to the community," he said.

" We envisage that, in time, probably two-thirds of pharmacies in the coming years in offering these services that the minister's announced. "

Mr Blacker says the community should feel confident as the system expands. (ABC News: Adam Kennedy)

Mr Blacker said a decade ago, vaccinations at pharmacies were a "rarity" but were now common.

"With these changes, making sure they're safe, making sure we have quality outcomes and making sure that patients appreciate and enjoy what the choice is for them ... in a timely manner, I think over the course of the next 10 years we'll see this help take pressure off the health system and patients, ultimately," he said.

" But it is a slow burn, but that allows it to be a safe transition. "

Asked if he expected any resistance from GPs about the change, he said they did hear some criticisms sometimes, but worked closely with doctors.

"But patients get the choice — you can choose," he said.

"It would be great if everyone had a regular GP, that's not the case unfortunately, but if we can help our GP colleagues and help the ACT health system, I think that's ultimately really good."

title: Breaking: Australia's unemployment rate jumps to 4.5pc
text:
Australia's unemployment rate jumped to 4.5 per cent in September, up from 4.3 per cent in August, in seasonally adjusted terms.

It is the highest seasonally adjusted unemployment rate recorded since November 2021.

An increase in both men and women seeking work contributed to the rise in the number of unemployed people in September.

The number of officially unemployed people rose by 33,900, and the number of those employed rose by 14,900, as the participation rate lifted by 0.1 percentage points to 67 per cent.

In trend terms, which attempts to smooth out seasonal noise from the data, the unemployment rate remained steady at 4.3 per cent.

title: 'Marathon Mitch' manages to finish 1,100km charity run with broken hip
text:
A man who ran more than 1,000 kilometres through the outback to raise money and awareness for a rare disorder managed to complete the final leg with a fractured hip.

Mitch McKenny spent four weeks pounding the bitumen highway between Broken Hill and Newcastle on his mission for Angelman syndrome, which his friend's child, Huxley Maguire, was diagnosed with at four months old.

The rare genetic condition affects the functioning of nerves in the brain and can cause physical and intellectual problems.

Near Narromine, some 715km into the 34-year-old's massive run, after averaging eight hours a day of running for about two weeks straight, he began to experience pain in his hip.

Mitch McKenny ran past canola fields near Dubbo. (Supplied: Huxley's Heroes)

Mr McKenny put it down to a pulled muscle and took the foot off the ignition for the 40km stretch between Narromine and Dubbo.

"[I was] under the impression at that stage that it was some kind of muscular injury or ligament injury," he said.

"[I] had a bit of a down-low kilometre day that day and the next day.

Ted Johnson rode his bike alongside Mitch McKenny into Dubbo. (ABC News: Nick Lowther)

"By the time I got to Dubbo, I was moving pretty slowly,"

As Mr McKenny ran into Dubbo, he was met by a cheering crowd and seven-year-old Ted Johnson, who, like Huxley, lives with Angelman syndrome.

With his pushbike, Ted accompanied "Marathon Mitch" as he made his way through town.

But Huxley's family, who had been following along behind Mr McKenny, knew something was wrong when they caught up with him again in Dubbo.

"He was in pain. That was evident," Jess Maguire said.

" But we nowhere near thought that the extent would be a break in the hip. "

Mitch McKenny is unsure when during his run he sustained his injury. (Supplied: Huxley's Heroes)

After pushing him to go to Dubbo Hospital, he was given a full physical exam, and doctors implored Mr McKenny to quit the run before he did serious damage, but he would not hear of it.

Instead, he hit the road again and miraculously finished the final 380km despite his pain growing rapidly worse.

As he arrived in Newcastle on September 19, it was to much fanfare and a neck femur fracture in his right hip.

Supporters celebrated with Mitch McKenny at Nobbys Beach in Newcastle. (ABC Newcastle: Keely Johnson)

In the process, he also raised more than $160,000 for the Foundation for Angelman Syndrome Therapeutics Australia (FAST).

Feat of strength and endurance

Nearly a month on, Mr McKenny is still confined to crutches and will be for the next six weeks, but has no regrets.

After undergoing X-rays and MRIs, it became apparent he had suffered a stress fracture somewhere on his massive run, although he is still not "100 per cent sure" where.

Mitch McKenny ran along major highways during the journey. (Supplied: Huxley's Heroes)

His Broken Hill GP quickly booked him in for surgery in Adelaide, which left him with a plate and a few pins in his right hip.

Thinking back on the run, he said he remembered being in pain, but mostly recalled pushing to finish.

"I think your mind has a way of blocking out those kinds of memories on the pain and that kind of stuff," Mr McKenny said.

"I'm aware that it took place, [and I'm] happy and proud that we achieved that feat for Huxley, but no plans to do it again."

Mr McKenny said he believed the curve of the roads he was running on was the likely cause of the stress fracture.

"[I was] running on the right-hand side of the road so that I could see the cars … for safety reasons," he said.

"There's camber on the road, which unevenly distributed, I suppose, the force between both legs, so after a few days or a week, that started to build up."

Mitch McKenny received a warm welcome when he ran into Dubbo. (ABC News: Nick Lowther)

It means his running days are behind him for now, but it was not something Mr McKenny said he felt too upset about.

Huxley's mothers, Bree and Jess Maguire, could not be prouder of Mr McKenny's efforts for their baby son and others who live with Angelman syndrome.

"It just goes to show again the drive and determination that he had to complete the run," Jess Maguire said.

"It's just incredible what he's done. You can't put it into words."

For now, Mr McKenny is taking a rest and looking forward to walking without crutches in six weeks' time.

title: Which team 'won' the AFL trade period — and does free agency need a fix?
text:
After a season's worth of speculation and a frantic last afternoon filled with star-filled moves (and almost-moves), the dust has finally started to settle on the 2025 AFL trade period.

This year's trade cycle was particularly action packed, with the most deals being made since 2018. As a result the league is set to take a somewhat different form in 2026.

This year's player movement period was headlined by some of the most prominent names in the game, with players such as Christian Petracca, Charlie Curnow, Clayton Oliver, Jack Steele, Tom De Koning, Oscar Allen, Brandon Starcevich, James Worpel, Will Hayward and Sam Flanders finding new homes for next year.

The draft order has also been up-ended, with four clubs holding the first eight picks in consecutive order at the present time.

While the whistle may have only been just blown on all the "action", some clear trends (and potential future winners) have already emerged from the off-season.

St Kilda going for broke

Just like the real game of football, the off-field game can be played in a variety of ways.

Some like to close shop to the media and pursue the small targets. Others focus on the draft and building "the right way".

A rarer group makes the decision to swing for the fences, in a hope to turn their fortunes around.

St Kilda is the standard bearer in 2025 for those looking to surge up the ladder in a hurry.

It's not the first time the Saints have made a big splash at the trade table. In 2019 the Saints traded in Dan Butler, Bradley Hill, Paddy Ryder, Dougal Howard and Zak Jones in a push to rise back up the ladder.

The injection of talent worked and the Saints played finals footy for the first time in nine years. But it was also relatively short-lived, with the Saints yo-yoing up and down the ladder since. With just one finals win since 2010 the time seemed to be now to strike.

With a relatively clean set of books the Saints were ready to add depth and talent to their list. The Saints have welcomed four high profile players into the club this offseason, with all set to contribute from day one.

All four of Tom De Koning, Liam Ryan, Sam Flanders and Jack Silvangi are set to be best 23 players next year, filling different roles across the ground.

De Koning is the player who is expected to have the biggest long term impact of any to find new clubs in 2026, with the new Saints ruck set to impact from day one at Moorabbin.

He is capable in the air and at ground level, and can catch opposition rucks napping when he floats forward.

Many expected Rowan Marshall to part ways with St Kilda to make room for the former Blue, but the Saints brain trust appears keen to pair the two mobile rucks together.

The twin towers should also help to bolster a forward line lacking in size and aerial contest ability inside 50 in recent years.

The only departures via trade were former captain Jack Steele and Max Heath — both going to Melbourne.

These acquisitions place immediate pressure on coach Ross Lyon and the Saints to repeat their 2020 rise up the ladder.

The Saints weren't the only club to look to solidify their side for next season, with the Cats and Giants looking to fill holes in their midfield with James Worpel and Clayton Oliver respectively.

Other sides looked at the longer term, with clubs like Melbourne and Carlton looking to accumulate draft picks for this and future years.

Some clubs worked hard to ensure they had enough picks to satisfy their father-son and academy talents both this year and next, with the Lions, Suns, Blues and Swans set to welcome prominent players in those cycles.

Greylands and the aging game

Christian Petracca earned more Brownlow Medal votes than any other player between 2021 and 2023.

Charlie Curnow kicked more goals than anyone in the league between 2022 and 2024.

Both are multiple time All Australians, amongst award-stuffed resumes.

And both are set to play for new clubs in 2026.

Petracca and Curnow aren't the only highly credentialed players to find new clubs via trade this off-season, but they have formed a class of their own as a result of their moves.

No club has spent more draft capital bringing in players their age or older over the last decade, with the trade packages for both stars outstripping prior deals such as the 2017 Bryce Gibbs trade and last year's move involving Tom Barrass.

It's a sign that clubs are becoming more willing to spend on older players than any before.

The average age of AFL players is older than any point in the last 100 years.There has been a re-evaluation of how long AFL players can contribute at the top level, alongside increased financial rewards for players keeping them in the game.

The large hauls are also a sign of clubs increasingly digging their heels in on moving contracted players to new clubs.

Deals for Marshall and Essendon captain Zach Merrett fell over at the last hurdle as their existing clubs asked for more for their valued (and long-tethered) players.

Even the Curnow deal came down to the last five minutes, with the inclusion of a Swans 2027 first rounder turning a Carlton refusal into a done deal. These trends may rebalance the entire trade landscape in future years.

Both Sydney and the Suns see themselves in the midst of premiership contention, and players of the calibre of Curnow and Petracca aren't available every year.

Neither player comes without questions. Both players are coming off a down year, and have extensive injury histories that they've battled through.

The on-field fit seems a little odd at face value as well, with Petracca joining one of the deepest midfield (and mid-forward) groups in the league, while Sydney has a large number of talented key position forwards (fitness pending).

Both clubs appear to be backing their coaching staff to make it work.

It's likely that they've given up more than they'll get back long term for both players, but it might just catapult them to the top of the premiership podium in the meantime.

Future future focus

For the first time clubs could trade picks two years in advance of the current draft class. This extra flexibility was set to open up the trade period, with extra currency floating about to get players to new homes.

Instead, clubs were hesitant to dip that far into the future just yet.

Inside the AFL's battle of generations The AFL approaches expansion at a time where there is more talent in the league than ever before courtesy of veterans extending their primes and young players entering the league ready to cause a splash right away.

Of the 62 picks traded so far, 42 were for this year's draft, 14 were for the 2026 draft and six are set for the 2027 draft. Just one of those 2027 picks traded was a first round selection — used in the Curnow deal.

This year's draft isn't considered to be a strong class due to the large number of top end talents tied to clubs via the father-son or academy pathways.

The depth has also been questioned, with this draft shaping to have fewer than the usual number of entry age level draftees chosen. As such, the higher than usual cost for players like Curnow may be explained by club views on the talent available for selection.

There are also likely a few reasons why clubs have been hesitant to trade two years in advance — or at least so far.

Firstly, there is flexibility from holding onto your picks going into each coming trade period. As evidenced by the chaos this year, few can predict who will become available year-on-year, or who might ask to leave.

AFL trade deadline day five quick hits The AFL trade period's deadline day delivered more drama than ever before as clubs and agents clashed in the pursuit of last-minute deals — some of which got over the line, and many of which fell through.

Secondly, the mooted entry of Tasmania is set to throw the draft and trade periods off-balance in several ways. Most directly, pending the confirmation of their entry into the league in 2028, the Devils will receive seven picks in the first round and the first pick in every round after that.

While Tassie has to trade many of those selections, it will push every other club down the draft order.

The Devils will also sign uncontracted players and free agents across the league, generating compensation selections that both slide other picks further down the order, and give clubs extra picks to play with.

Tasmania will also have access to underage players a year out from the draft, likely diluting the pool by removing top players in advance of the actual draft.

All in all, a mid-first round pick in 2027 — such as the pick Carlton just picked up from Sydney — might end up beyond 20th in the actual draft order and be vying for only 30th best 18 year old in the country.

Does free agency need fixing?

This player movement period also laid out the warts of the current AFL free agency system, with clubs working to maximise the compensation picks generated and circumvent some of the equalisation mechanisms set out by the league.

The most prominent example of this is the trade of Brandon Starcevich from Brisbane to West Coast in order to preserve the compensation pick awarded for Oscar Allen's move the other way.

Starcevich was a free agent coming into the offseason, but if he had moved as a free agent this would have offset some of the value of the Allen move and moved West Coast's freshly minted pick two back a round or two.

Both clubs involved ended up ahead in picks, at the expense of the other sixteen clubs in the league. The Eagles and Lions weren't the only clubs involved in such moves either, with Melbourne trading Brody Mihocek in, rather than signing in free agency to preserve their compensation for losing Charlie Spargo.

There also remains questions about the high level of compensation awarded for lost players. It is understood that the league benchmarks player salaries in upcoming years against past salaries, potentially inflating the picks awarded to clubs.

With clubs across the league knowing the broad inputs to the compensation formula, it is unsurprising that clubs are working to maximise the return for their players by any means necessary.

It's also why the free agency system is overdue for review in the coming years.

title: Rental affordability report shows essential workers being priced out of housing
text:
Cody Nesbit dreams of owning a home but the Gold Coast barista is struggling to save and says it's hard to see light at the end of the tunnel.

He's not alone, a new report from Anglicare has revealed less than 1 per cent of rentals in Queensland were affordable for the average hospitality worker.

According to the annual Rental Affordability Snapshot, a bartender who wanted to live alone could not afford a single property in the ACT, only five in the Northern Territory and just 80 across the whole of Victoria.

The situation is not much better for paramedics, aged care professionals, nurses, delivery drivers and early childhood educators who are being priced out of the rental market across the country.

Mr Nesbit manages a popular cafe in Mermaid Beach and pays $400 per week for a room in a Miami share house he rents with three other people.

"Rent has gone up dramatically every year," Mr Nesbit said.

"Everything has gone up. The only thing that hasn't gone up is our wage."

Barista Cody Nesbit says it is difficult for Gold Coast hospitality workers to save money. (ABC News: Nicole Dyer)

The 35-year-old is studying teaching and hopes to land a job at an outback school when he graduates, where he hopes the cost of living will be lower than the coast.

It's a sacrifice he said will allow him and his partner to save for a deposit.

"My partner and I chat a lot about what the future holds for us and what we need to do, and the outcome seems grim," he said.

"We want to be able to afford to have a house, we want to be able to afford to have kids.

"You used to be able to go out and enjoy a night on the town, buy your groceries, pay your bills and still be able to put some money aside — that's gone now."

Many full-time workers are being forced to move away from capital cities for cost of living relief. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

Affordability 'going backwards'

Anglicare's annual Rental Affordability Snapshot has laid bare the impact of Australia's housing crisis and rising cost of living on essential workers.

The study surveyed 51,000 rental listings nationwide and tested them against the full-time wages of 16 frontline occupations communities cannot function without.

It found early childhood staff could afford just 0.8 per cent of rental properties, 1.1 per cent were affordable for a cleaner, 1.5 per cent for nurses, 2.3 per cent for ambulance officers and 3.3 per cent for school teachers.

On the Gold Coast, one of the country's most expensive rental markets, the report revealed someone on minimum wage would only be able to afford two of the 1,563 available rentals.

Anglicare Australia executive director Kasy Chambers said it was a "national disgrace" that hard-working people struggled to keep a roof over their head.

"This report shows that even full-time workers in critical jobs are locked out of most rentals," Ms Chambers said.

"If they cannot afford to live where they work then schools, hospitals, and aged care homes will struggle to keep running."

Anglicare Australia executive director Kasy Chambers says the housing crisis is a result of decades of poor policy. (AAP Image: Lukas Coch)

Despite the number of listings growing by 13 per cent, there was no significant increase in affordability for essential workers.

The study found there was little relief outside of the capital cities, which according to Anglicare dispelled the "myth" that people struggling to afford rent should simply move to a regional area.

Mr Nesbit said he was frustrated that many older people assumed his generation did not have sensible spending habits.

He said he knew many people in the hospitality industry who worked second jobs or had moved back in with their parents.

"We all work really hard," he said

"It has been tough. Everyone is in the same boat."

Ms Chambers said Australia's housing crisis was a manufactured problem and governments needed to urgently change course to solve it.

"It is a system that works for investors, but shuts out everyone else," she said.

"The solution is clear: we need tax reform to stop pushing up the cost of housing, we need to build at least 25,000 new public and community homes each year and we need stronger protections for renters, so people are not left at the mercy of an unfair system."

title: Remote sheep station 'turbocharged' by water supply hits the market
text:
Weeks after the West Australian government approved the transfer of Rawlinna Station on the Nullarbor Plain to a UK-based pastoral company, another of Australia's largest sheep stations has been listed for sale without price.

Madura Plains Station is located 700 kilometres east of Kalgoorlie, near the West Australian and South Australian borders and is intersected by the Eyre Highway.

Considered one of the most productive sheep stations in WA, last shearing saw 76,000 head of merinos pass through its gates.

In such a remote location, available water on the property through artesian and groundwater bores has a long history of attracting graziers and highway travellers, and today an extensive 1,400 kilometre pipeline network for stock watering is considered a jewel in its crown.

Madura Plains has 206 water points supplied by bores. (Supplied: Elders Real Estate)

Elders Real Estate divisional CEO Tom Russo said water from three bore-fields now reached 206 water points across the station through solar-powered pumps, which were remotely accessible through a telemetry system.

"You can sit in your home in a capital city and look at every single water point in that property in real time and understand what is going on," he said.

"It's extraordinary, [the water development] has turbocharged the property and really opened up those saltbush plains … its production capacity is enormous.

" In a good or an average season, I think you can assume it can run 60,000 sheep very easily, but when things are really good, things can ramp up, as we saw last year. "

Wind and solar monitoring

Almost 150 years have passed since European settlers first established a homestead and horse breeding enterprise for the British Army at the property.

In 1935, South Australian newspaper the Kimba Dispatch described "a mighty artesian bore" on Madura, producing hot water which was a popular bathing spot for people in the region, "even swaggies".

Sheep at Madura graze on saltbush and bluebush plains. (Supplied: Elders Real Estate)

Over the years, the station has seen rabbit plagues, bushfires, people absconding from the law and the discovery of mysterious bones, all while sheep and cattle grazed its saltbush and bluebush plains.

Its future may also include renewable energy.

"This property sits right in the middle of the Western Green Energy Hub. If it came through, it would be one of the biggest, if not the biggest, hydrogen projects in the world," Mr Russo said.

"There's a lot of data being collected off the property around wind and solar output … whoever buys this property will be very confident that in some point in time there is going to be additional revenue coming from a project of that nature.

"I don't think it would materially interfere with the pastoral operation, the two can coexist nicely."

An extensive off-grid solar system has been built on the property. (Supplied: MyEnergy Engineering)

The 711,638 hectare property is currently owned by the South Australian-based Cooper family, which purchased Madura from agribusiness Jumbuck in 2016.

Its listing comes after Consolidated Pastoral Company purchased nearby Rawlinna Station for an undisclosed sum.

CPC has made clear its focus is to revitalise Rawlinna and return it to significant sheep and wool production.

Madura is fenced into 118 paddocks. (Supplied: Elders Real Estate)

Mr Russo said it was a "fortunate coincidence" the listing of Madura followed the Rawlinna sale.

"It's being offered in a really good market … I think we'll see a big field of really good candidates, both existing incumbent pastoralists and bigger institutional investors having a good hard look at it," he said.

"The outlook for sheep is really good, the wool market is coming back strongly, which is well overdue."

Madura will be sold with approximately 40,000 head of sheep.

title: Auditor-general says Victoria risks losing flood recovery money
text:
The Victorian Auditor-General says state government agencies need to speed up flood-related claims and not miss out on Commonwealth funding.

The points are among four recommendations laid out in a 40-page report evaluating the Victorian government's response to the October 2022 floods.

The auditor-general questioned whether relief and recovery efforts were sent quickly enough to people in Rochester, Shepparton, Echuca and Maribyrnong and if the money spent was justified.

Tracie Kyne says red tape has held up insurance claims. (ABC News: Tyrone Dalton)

"It was clearly obvious that 988 homes [in Rochester] were inundated with water during that 2022 flood," Rochester Flood Mitigation Group member Tracie Kyne said.

" It took so long for funding to come through to those who needed it most and were desperate for assistance. The red tape was just beyond ridiculous. "

The Victorian Auditor-General's Office (VAGO) found that then Treasurer Tim Pallas approved $981.2 million in recovery funding within a fortnight of the floods, but it took up to six weeks for food relief, waste and debris disposal and free kindergarten for families to be made available to affected residents.

VAGO found the Victorian government had spent $1.66 billion on flood recovery to June 2023, but requests made by departments to the Commonwealth lacked documentation, evidence and rationale to justify the spending.

The auditor-general's office said that because of this, the Victorian government could miss out on some funding through the Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements.

Rochester residents say assistance from the Victorian government for food relief and clean-up took too long. (ABC News: Michael Lorigan)

In February this year, a letter from the federal Minister for Emergency Services, Senator Jenny McAllister, revealed the Victorian government did not apply for a co-funding arrangement with the Commonwealth to establish a build-back-better housing scheme.

Ms Kyne and fellow group member, Leigh Wilson, have led calls for the Victorian government to futureproof flood-prone towns by building homes higher and improving water management at basins and reservoirs.

A parliamentary inquiry into the 2022 floods made 73 recommendations to the government, of which the government accepted 16 in full in January.

Assessors held up funding claims

The Victorian Auditor-General found that assessors working for the Department of Transport and Planning held up the release of funding by requesting more information from local government organisations in 65 per cent of the cases.

It said in most cases, regional councils had met submission deadlines, but that by sending the requests all at once towards the end of a financial year, it created a high workload for the department.

Member for Northern Victoria and Liberal Party MP, Wendy Lovell, said the delay in funding from the Victorian government for 77 outstanding projects meant communities could not complete important projects.

"We also see in this report that it's taken them 214 days on average to assess the claims, and that's a very long time," she said.

"That's over seven months, so we're now three years out from the floods, and we've still got projects that haven't been progressed.

"This just shows how slow the flood recovery has been."

Rural Councils Victoria secretary Bradley Thomas said VAGO's report was a good opportunity to review the claims process councils had to go through to repair public assets.

Bradley Thomas says the floods claims process was "burdensome." (Supplied: Rural Councils Victoria)

Mr Thomas said rural councils experienced a lot of natural disasters, and the claims process had become very "burdensome" and "very bureaucratic,".

"It's a really complicated process, and we think the report calls that out in part," he said.

VAGO said it was clear that the Department of Transport and Planning, the body responsible for assessing flood-related funding claims, was not meeting its target of assessing claims within four weeks of being lodged.

It acknowledged that the times had improved from their peak in May 2023 of 429 days.

VAGO wants the department to double the number of assessors it employs and simplify assessments for low-value claims.

The VAGO report found that all claims made by local councils in the 2022-23 financial year met Commonwealth funding requirements, but since then $15.6 million (or 5.8 per cent) of claims made by Victorian government departments for Commonwealth funding were ineligible because not enough evidence was provided.

That resulted in pressure on the Department of Transport and Planning and Emergency Recovery Victoria.

The report says regional councils are still submitting their certified estimates and will have waited more than three years for public assets to be restored.

The Victorian government has been contacted for comment.

title: Victorian schools to limit screen time, provide free laptops
text:
Students in Victorian primary schools will have screen time limited in class and parents will not have to pay for laptops under major changes to the state's education guidelines.

The reforms aim to curtail the amount of time students spend on laptops, which the government said had accelerated since the pandemic.

Children in prep to year 2 will have minimal access to screens, while year 3 to 6 students will spend no more than 90 minutes a day on screens.

Schools will also be required to ensure all students have access to a laptop, which the government said would mean parents would not have to buy the devices.

Screen time will be limited to 90 minutes a day for students in years 3 to 6. (ABC News: Brooke Chandler)

Education Minister Ben Carroll said it was a major change to the way schools use screens in the classroom.

"This is a massive shake-up for the education system in Victoria. This will save parents money and it will also improve outcomes for kids," he said.

"We want an education system that fosters critical thinking, creativity and collaboration.

" We've already got phone-free schools, now we're going to have screen-free schools. "

Victoria's Education Minister Ben Carroll said schools will ensure all students have access to a laptop. (ABC News: Nico White)

Mr Carroll said the reforms go hand in hand with the social media ban and Victoria's ban on mobile phones at schools.

"A reliance on screens is having a big impact on behavioural issues, having a big impact on our students' concentration in the classroom," he said.

"These are really important reforms in the digital age. We know children born today are digital natives, but we want them to have a childhood as well, be out in the playground, be fostering those social relationships."

The screen time limits will be mandatory at all Victorian state primary schools from 2027.

The Australian Education Union (AEU) said the laptop commitment was "laughable" and that schools would not have the money to pay for it.

"Not requiring parents to pay for tablets or laptops is a good thing — they should never have had to in the first place," AEU Victorian Branch president Justin Mullaly said.

"But the Allan government is living in a dreamland if they think public schools have the budgets available to provide devices to all students, when Victorian public schools are the lowest funded in the nation.

"There is no way that Victoria's public primary schools will be able to ensure students have access to up-to-date technology and secure devices unless the premier stops the con-job and fixes her public school funding mess."

Principals and parents cautiously welcome changes

President of the Victorian Principals Association, Andrew Dalgleish, said the changes would probably receive "mixed responses" from schools.

He said parents might find it easier to allocate screen time at home if they know how much time their child has spent on a device at school.

"I don't think it's as much of an issue in schools as it is at home," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.

Toddlers' screen time impacts the words they learn Toddlers who get more screen time could be learning fewer new words, an Australian study finds, warning parents of the opportunity cost of distracting children with devices.

However, he said it was important that schools had certainty over access to proper equipment for online learning.

"I think that will be the biggest challenge. We know that the cost of technology has a large impact on families and a large impact on schools," he said.

"We certainly found during the pandemic when we pivoted to online learning that there were supports that were needed from the department in some cases, and they stepped up to that."

Mr Dalgleish said the move to conduct NAPLAN test exclusively online also present a challenge for schools.

"Those schools that have modern devices that are right to go, that will be fine," he said.

"For those that need to prepare for it there will need to be some work to ensure that every child has a device at the time they need to sit that test."

The reforms aim to reduce the amount of time children spend on devices in the school environment. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

Parents Victoria chief executive Gail McHardy said the government needed to find the right balance with its reforms.

"We need to use technology to enhance learning, not to inhibit, and I think this is the problem with all the distractions and things," she told ABC Radio Melbourne.

"For parents, all they ask for at any given time is to have clarity about what is going on so they can balance it up at home.

" Children come home and they jump on their devices because mum and dad might still be working or they might be saying they didn't have device time at school. "

Ms McHardy said she appreciated the government's commitment to providing laptops at schools, but wanted assurances that the equipment was up to scratch.

title: Olympic swimming champion Titmus explains shock retirement
text:
Australia's four-time Olympic gold medallist Ariarne Titmus has retired from all levels of swimming.

Swimming Australia confirmed the 25-year-old's retirement on Thursday morning.

Titmus finished her career as one of the greatest distance swimmers of all time, having won eight Olympic medals across the Paris and Tokyo Games.

Coached by Dean Boxall, Titmus also claimed nine world championship (long course) medals, including four gold.

She took an extended break from swimming following the Paris Olympics, before deciding to retire.

"It's a tough one but one that I'm really happy with," Titmus said in an Instagram post.

"I've always loved swimming, it's been my passion since I was a little girl.

"But I guess I've taken this time away from the sport and realised some things in my life that have always been important to me are just a little bit more important to me now than swimming.

"That's OK, but here we are."

Ariarne Titmus represented Australia at two Olympics. (Getty Images: John Walton/PA Images)

Titmus successfully defended her Olympic title in the women's 400 metres freestyle at the Paris Olympics.

She became the first Australian female athlete since Dawn Fraser in 1964 to win back-to-back gold medals in the same event.

In the Tokyo 400m freestyle final, Titmus defeated legendary American Katie Ledecky, who was defending champion and the world-record holder at the time.

Four years later, she beat home rising Canadian star Summer McIntosh and Ledecky in the final, a showdown dubbed the "race of the century".

Ariarne Titmus successfully defended her Olympic title in the women's 400m freestyle at the Paris Games. (Reuters: Grace Hollars)

Titmus said retirement was not on her mind when she competed in Paris last year.

"I always intended to return. I never thought Paris would be my last Olympic Games," she said.

"Knowing what I know now, maybe I wish I had enjoyed that last race a little bit more.

"I guess in these 12 months I've been able to explore what life is like outside of swimming."

Loading Instagram content

Titmus's haul of Olympic gold includes the women's 200m freestyle at the Tokyo Games and the 4x200m freestyle in Paris.

She came close to completing the 200m-400m freestyle double in Paris, finishing second to fellow Australian and training partner, Mollie O'Callaghan, in the shorter distance.

Titmus was twice Olympic silver medallist in the 800m freestyle, with Ledecky winning on both occasions.

Titmus remains world-record holder

Titmus also set world records in the 200m and 400m freestyle, with her time in the former — one minute and 52.23 seconds — still standing.

Swimming the time at the 2024 Australian Olympic trials in Brisbane, she became the first Australian woman since Shane Gould in 1972 to concurrently hold the 200m and 400m freestyle world records.

She twice broke the 400m freestyle world record during her career, with her personal best of 3:55.38 bettered by McIntosh (3:54.18) in June this year.

Ariarne Titmus (left) enjoyed a fierce but friendly rivalry with Katie Ledecky. (Getty Images: Quinn Rooney)

The Brisbane-based swimmer — who grew up in Tasmania — was a nominee for the 2025 Laureus World Comeback of the Year award for her performances at the Paris Olympics after she recovered from surgery to remove an ovarian tumour.

She described the health scare as a "turning point", forcing her to re-assess her life outside the pool.

"It probably was the first time where I considered some things outside of swimming," Titmus said.

"Delving more into those health challenges, I've really had to look within and think about what's most important to me and beyond swimming.

"I've always had goals in my personal life, but swimming has always been most important up until this point and I've just realised that those goals and what I want in my future is now more important to me.

"But more than anything, I'm excited for what's next."

Titmus's success extended to the Commonwealth Games, where she claimed seven gold medals and a silver at the Birmingham (2022) and Gold Coast (2018) editions.

title: R360 hits back at ARLC's threat of 10-year bans for rebel players
text:
R360 organisers have swiftly hit back at the Australian Rugby League Commission (ARLC), labelling threats of 10-year bans for players joining the breakaway competition as "sadly" predictable.

ARLC chairman Peter V'landys on Wednesday accused R360 officials of counterfeiting the code and vowed to also suspend any player managers involved.

NRL players face 10-year ban for joining rebel leagues The Australian Rugby League Commission has announced a 10-year ban for any NRL player who agrees to join a football competition it does not recognise.

The proposed ban would include exclusion from the NRL and any ARLC-sanctioned competition.

R360 co-chief executive Mark Spoors said the new concept was about offering players "fresh opportunities".

"Recent announcements, sadly, have been anticipated," Spoors said.

"History shows that when athletes are offered free choice and given fresh opportunities for them and their families, then threats to those sportsmen and women follow.

"R360 is about empowering players, giving them, rugby lovers and the next generation of fans opportunities and new platforms to enjoy the sport we love.

"We know there is much interest in understanding more about the global series we're building. We remain on plan and look forward to sharing and discussing the detail in the coming months.

"That will include details of the exciting male and female playing talent who will participate in R360 when we kick off in October 2026."

NRL stars Ryan Papenhuyzen, Cameron Munster, Payne Haas and Roger Tuivasa-Sheck are among those who have been linked to potential moves to R360.

Broncos prop Payne Haas is rumoured to be a target of R360 organisers. (AAP: Dave Hunt)

The competition is slated to start in late 2026 in a global, F1-style format with rounds in Cape Town, Tokyo and Dubai.

"The Commission has a clear duty to act in the best interests of rugby league and its fans," V'landys said in a strongly worded statement on Wednesday.

"We will take all necessary steps to protect the future of the game."

The ARLC's hardline stance comes after the league met last week with the 17 NRL clubs, who asked for action against any defecting players and their managers.

The official response came after the ARLC sought legal advice.

The development also follows Rugby Australia's warning that any player who joins R360 will be banned from representing the Wallabies, Wallaroos or Australia at the Olympics.

The Rugby League Players' Association (RLPA) is warning banned players would likely challenge the NRL in court.

"No-one wants to see players leaving the NRL or NRLW," RLPA chief executive Clint Newton said.

"But the RLPA is uncertain about the legal basis or enforceability of the proposed bans.

"We are concerned this is destined to be tested and decided in an Australian courtroom."

AAP

title: Australian wine labels feeling the pinch as Chinese buy and drink less
text:
China appears to no longer be the golden goose it once was for Australian wine exports, as demand slackens for even prestigious labels.

Penfolds owner Treasury Wine Estates (TWE) this week announced it would sell less of the luxury label in China than had previously been forecast.

It comes off the back of changing drinking habits and a reported crackdown on lavish banquets for civil servants.

Premium wines have in recent years been the best performers for Australian exports into the once-booming Chinese market, but changing economic conditions have taken their toll on the industry.

Wine Economics Research Centre executive director Kym Anderson said belt-tightening, health concerns and tariff wars had all hit the global wine trade.

Kym Anderson says it is hard to predict if and when the Chinese market will turn around. (Supplied: Kym Anderson)

"It's true in lots of countries, not just China, that the uncertainty that Trump has introduced into global markets generally has reduced people's confidence in both spending and investing, and in China that's certainly the case," Professor Anderson said.

He said the impact was now being felt "across the board".

"Rich people also get hit when these times are less certain, so they're probably reducing as well," he said.

"In addition, during that period of COVID there was still a flood of imports [and] people were expecting consumption to keep growing rapidly, and it didn't.

"So there were big stocks of wines, including premium wines, that were just sitting there needing to be cleared once the market opened up again, so that's dampened growth in imports in recent times as well."

While Australian producers of cheaper, bulk-produced wines have been battling other challenges, those making more premium label wines have still been largely enjoying good demand in key markets like China after the lifting of hefty tariffs on Australia wine post-COVID.

Some Australian premium wines will need to find new markets. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

About 96 million litres of Australian wine worth more than $1billion was exported to China last financial year — a volume almost half of what it was at its peak in 2018.

Industry-wide impacts

Professor Anderson said it was another concern for the troubled wine industry that the top and bottom end of wines were being impacted.

"It's affecting all different classes of wine," he said.

" Iconic wines are the least worried I suppose, but the standard super-premiums and so on, as well as the low-end stuff, it seems is being affected now. "

In an announcement this week to the ASX, TWE said Penfolds sales in China softened in June and July, which it put down to changing consumer habits and less "large-scale banqueting occasions".

Earlier this year global media outlets reported on new austerity regulations by Chinese officials targeting excessive drinking at banquets, which had affected alcohol sales within the country.

While it noted some uplift in the past two months, TWE said it no longer expected to reach its forecast Penfolds sales this year in China.

Penfolds is one of the premium brands affected by a downturn in demand from Chinese consumers. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

Due to that and challenges with its distribution network in California, TWE paused an on-market share buy-back "until there is greater clarity around trading conditions and expectations".

Industry ups and downs

Penfolds chief winemaker Peter Gago said cost-of-living challenges meant it was a tough time for wine, but it was part of the cycle of the industry.

"Everything's about ebb and flow — it's agriculture, so it's all about cycles and you just have to broaden your base," Mr Gago said.

"A nation of 1.4 billion people will also go through cycles.

" So yes, times are tough — a bit more difficult perhaps at the moment in a relative sense, but good times will come again and so it's just a matter of hanging in there. "

It is not just the big players that are noticing dwindling demand for premium wines into China.

Patrick of Coonawarra received approval to send its wines into China once restrictions were lifted in 2024.

Luke Tocaciu says the business has been able to maintain a steady demand for its wine in China. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

While demand started off strong, owner Luke Tocaciu said it had since become tougher to sell wine into China and his focus had turned to nations such as Indonesia and Canada.

"It's not as in demand as it has been previously," he said.

"We won't be putting all of our export eggs in that basket — some of the emerging markets are certainly something I'm trying to get a foot in the door."

title: $5 milk and $90 rent rises: NT cost of living pushing families into housing stress
text:
A rising number of families are being pushed into housing stress in the Northern Territory, according to a new report, as costs of living continue to climb.

The report found the cost of NT rentals has soared to near Sydney prices, and residents are facing some of the highest fuel prices and household bills in the country.

Sharply climbing costs have forced Kerrie Matthews and her husband to put their home, on the outskirts of Darwin, on the market, just two years after relocating to the NT from Victoria to live out their retirement.

The pensioners thought the territory would be a more affordable place to live, but their bills have since climbed to levels they can no longer afford.

After a recent water bill that reached $800 for a quarter, Ms Matthews stopped watering the garden, and her electricity bill has also risen steeply.

She said the thought of going to a restaurant or cafe was now a distant memory.

Kerrie Matthews says she has had to sell items to afford the insulin pump she relies on for her diabetes. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

"I'm a type 1 diabetic, so a lot of things that I use to stay alive [are] subsidised by the government," she said.

"I've been recently put on an insulin pump, but I have to pay for that.

"In order to not eat into the budget, I've actually been selling things.

"The pump is saving my life every day.

"I thought our lifestyle would be so much better up here, so it's very disappointing."

The NT has long had affordability issues, but according to a cost of living report released by the NT Council of Social Service (NTCOSS) on Thursday, they have become "extreme", and are hitting low-income households the hardest.

Interstate investors swarm NT homes Interstate investors are targeting homes across the Northern Territory, buying them up hours before they hit the market.

Darwin is now the second-most expensive place to rent a home in the country, only behind New South Wales.

Spurred by a very low vacancy rate and an influx of interstate investors targeting the NT, the average weekly rent for a three-bedroom house in the city has risen to $668.

The NTCOSS report found that in Darwin, someone on JobSeeker would spend almost 100 per cent of their payment on a one-bedroom unit, leaving just $20 to survive on.

NT Shelter chief executive Annie Taylor said residents were being priced out of the private rental market and forced to join "a social housing waitlist that's already impossibly long".

The report also said the average household power bill for a four-person home had risen $30 over the past year, and that Darwin had become the third-most expensive capital city for transport, behind Hobart and Melbourne.

While in most of Australia petrol prices fell from record highs this year, the NT did not experience the same drop — especially outside of the capital city, where fuel is close to the national average.

In Alice Springs, households are spending almost $1,500 more each year on petrol than in Darwin, according to the report.

And at $3.37 a litre, the Tiwi Islands — 80 kilometres north of Darwin and home to about 3,000 people — is one of the most expensive places to fill up a tank in the country.

As more people face financial hardship in the NT, Foodbank Darwin manager Jack Barrett said demand for their services had risen sharply, driving even people with jobs to seek assistance.

The Darwin Foodbank is seeing a rise in people needing help every month. (ABC News: Roxanne Fitzgerald )

"Our numbers are going up month on month on month," he said.

He said the affordability crisis was hitting people so hard that 60 per cent of families accessing Foodbank had at least one person in employment, and one third of families had a mortgage.

"That's families who have worked really hard, saved a deposit and still find themselves in need of help," he said.

In Booraloola, lactose-free milk costs $4.60 — more than double the cost in major supermarkets — while Pauls milk costs $5.70. (Supplied)

The report said when shopping for groceries in NT remote communities, residents can pay more than triple the price for the same item sold in cities.

As of October, 1 litre of lactose-free milk on the shelf of a remote community store in Booroloola cost $4.60, compared to $2 at a major supermarket, while a 1L bottle of long-life milk cost $5.70.

A150-gram jar of instant coffee cost $26 at the remote store — almost double what it would cost elsewhere.

A 150g jar of Nescafe costs $26 at a store in Borroloola, almost double the price it would be at a major supermarket. (Supplied)

"People who are on fixed incomes and low incomes … those people are doing it incredibly tough," NTCOSS chief executive Sally Sievers said.

"We've seen things like in Palmerston, a one-bedroom unit, the rent increasing by $90 just in a 12-month period.

"People are having to make really difficult decisions about going to the doctor or affording medication."

About 1.3 million low-income households across Australia experienced housing stress in 2024–25, defined as spending more than 30 per cent of their disposable income on housing, according to a separate report released by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare on Thursday.

According to the NTCOSS report, the NT's remote area allowance has not increased in decades and current concessions are too limited to keep pace.

Sally Sievers says the cost-of-living crisis is having a big impact on people on lower incomes. (ABC News: Roxanne Fitzgerald)

"The people on the lowest incomes are carrying the greatest burden," Ms Sievers said.

"Governments must act where relief will make the most difference. That means targeted cost-of-living measures for those doing it toughest."

The NT government has been contacted for comment.

title: NSW city's time to shine in event that is 'a bit like the Olympics'
text:
Wollongong turned on perfect conditions for the World Triathlon Championship Finals opening ceremony, with the New South Wales south coast city's picturesque harbour awash with colour, sound and patriotism.

Nearly 5,000 athletes from across the globe will compete over the next four days in what organisers say is the biggest annual multi-sport event in the world.

"It's a bit like the Olympics," World Triathlon Championship general manager Mark Emerton said.

" Each country picked a flag bearer, with a sign for the country. "

Athletes on their way to the opening night procession of the 2025 World Triathlon Championships. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Australia will field the largest team, comprising 1,500 competitors aged between 18 and 85, including 13 para triathletes.

The US, UK and New Zealand follow close behind, with a Fijian trio the event's smallest squad.

About 800 local volunteers have also signed on.

"We've got one of the biggest races and richest prizes in the world here in Wollongong this week, which is goddamn exciting," Mr Emerton said.

Back-to-back action

The first round of races begins on Thursday with the under-23 men's and women's events, followed by junior men and women's races on Friday and all para-triathlete events on Saturday.

Hundreds of Australian athletes gave their all in Wollongong during April's qualifying event. (ABC Illawarra: Brooke Chandler)

"We have a community-run event that night called the Rock and Run which is a 2-kilometre or 5km lap around the lighthouse," Mr Emerton said.

The professional competitors will take to the course on Sunday.

"They'll be competing for $500,000 in prize money," Mr Emerton said.

" They are the ones who will be knocking on the door to represent their country at the next Olympics. "

Vying for the podium

Wollongong will be the fourth world championship final for para-triathlete Anu Francis, a year after she made her Paralympic debut in Paris.

Anu Francis won a silver medal at the 2024 Paris Paralympics. (Supplied: Anu Francis)

The 30-year-old Adelaide local, who has a genetic connective tissue disorder known as Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, will compete using a modified bike and crutches.

"The last couple of months have been the most consistent I've ever trained, like the most volume I've ever handled," she said.

"The body is feeling amazing."

Women's world number four Jeanne Lehair from Luxembourg said she was keen to take on Wollongong's difficult course.

Jeanne Lehair is in Australia for the first time. (ABC Illawarra: Brooke Chandler)

"Usually when it's flat we are bored," she said.

"So I think it's good for the race because it's a bit more challenging.

"The only thing is I prefer a lake swim than ocean and I don't really like beach starts."

Luke Willian says he knows the Wollongong course well after winning the 2024 World Triathlon Cup in the city. (ABC Radio Brisbane: Dean Caton)

Australia's number two Luke Willian, 29, said he was excited to compete on home soil, surrounded by family.

"I remember watching Emma Moffatt win the World Championship in 2009 as a 13-year-old kid and that gave me heaps of motivation … to do that one day," he said.

" I am really fortunate I get to live out that dream. "

Why Wollongong?

Australia has not hosted the World Triathlon Championship Finals since 2018, when the event was run on the Gold Coast.

Mr Emerton said Wollongong was the perfect location due to its rough terrain, proximity to Sydney International Airport, and experience hosting the UCI Road World Championships in 2022.

The UCI Road World Championships exposed Wollongong to a global audience. (ABC Illawarra: Justin Huntsdale)

"We've got a nice harbour to swim in, we've got a nice bike course to ride along the coastline," he said.

"I'm a bit biased but we went to Spain [for the World Triathlon Championship Finals] last year, their course is nowhere near as nice as Wollongong's."

Some marina businesses have raised concerns about potential revenue loss from road closures and restricted pedestrian access during the event.

"Each competitor is given a voucher to spend locally so if a cafe gets 20 vouchers, we'll go back and pay for those vouchers," Mr Emerton said.

"We've really tried hard to ensure an international event is integrated well into the city."

title: Inside the plan to rebuild Juukan Gorge rock shelter destroyed by Rio Tinto
text:
A full-scale replica of the Juukan Gorge cave, destroyed in 2020 by mining company Rio Tinto to an avalanche of international condemnation, will be built around the remains of the original in Western Australia's north.

Used by Indigenous people for 47,000 years, it was blasted in 2020 in a legally sanctioned move to expand one the company's Pilbara iron ore mines.

Five years on, an enormous feat of engineering and artistry is underway to build a realistic re-creation to then place on country as part of the site's rehabilitation.

While the cost and timeline for completion is unclear, Rio Tinto itself is footing the bill as part of its redress agreement with Traditional Owners.

The Juukan Gorge caves in WA's Pilbara in 2013 (L), and after the land was cleared (R) in 2020 before the site was blasted. (Supplied: PKKP)

Filling the void

Puutu Kunti Kurrama Land Committee chair Burchell Hayes said the new shelter aimed to restore Indigenous Australians' sense of belonging to the area by remediating damage caused by Rio Tinto.

Burchell Hayes says preserving the rock shelter's legacy is a priority. (ABC News: Mya Kordic)

Mr Hayes said while it was unclear what cultural significance the replica would bring once it was complete, he knew his people did not want to be left with a permanent void on the landscape.

He said they were inspired "to ensure that something was placed back there to resemble what our memories of the gorge and the rock shelter looked like for us".

"It is a significant cultural feature on our country, and we want to make sure that future generations continue to be able to come out on country and see what was possible and what was achieved."

The goal is to recreate the original shelter as closely as possible. (ABC News: Mitchell Edgar)

Immersive experience

The project is in its early stages, but impressive results were already emerging.

In a studio in Perth's Osborne Park, technicians developed an immersive, virtual reality recreation of the rock shelter based off a collection of about 150 photos, and the memories of Indigenous people.

The designers will use that to construct physical pieces of the cave to eventually be transported to the Pilbara and assembled on site.

You can put on a virtual reality headset and find yourself in the Pilbara looking at that cracked western wall. The digital version of Juukan is then superimposed on top. (ABC News: Mya Kordic)

Daniel Browne, the director of CDM Studios, said his team created the first digital version and took it to Traditional Owners who would say they remembered a particular feature, like a specific rock, a 'moon pool' or a hole in the roof, and that would be added in.

"Every recollection we can get will help piece this cave together," Mr Browne said.

Daniel Browne is working with traditional owners to get the replica as close to the original as possible. (ABC News: Mya Kordic)

" This is a very, very unique challenge to build a super realistic hard scape that has to be there for hundreds of years into the future, that has to exist in that environment. "

French inspiration

As part of the project, a delegation from the Puutu Kunti Kurrama (PKKP) and Pinikura Aboriginal Corporation is in France visiting similar replicas of the famous Lascaux and Chauvet caves.

Located in south-western and south-eastern France, the caves are some of the most celebrated and visited prehistoric sites in the country.

Lascaux IV is an exact replica of the original cave in Dordogne. (Supplied: Lascaux.fr)

Hundreds of animal paintings on the walls of Chauvet have been dated to 36,000 years ago, and more than 17,000 years in Lascaux.

In the case of the Chauvet replica, huge steel structures were sprayed with a layer of mortar and natural pigments to create an identical copy of the original cave.

Artists then recreated each detail of the cave surface and reproduced each animal painting in detail.

Construction on the Chauvet 2 replica cave began in 2012. (Supplied: grottechauvet2ardeche.com)

The Chauvet cave cost almost $100 million ($55m Euros) and took eight years to build.

"We want to understand what went into the design and the construction ... how they were able to use the original traditional methods of painting those stencils on the cave," Mr Hayes said.

Models are being used to make sure the replica is as close to the original as possible. (ABC News: Mya Kordic)

The PKKP's director of land and heritage Denis Coutant said the French cave recreations were done to minimise damage by tourists and used 3D scans to exactly map out every feature.

The Juukan rock shelter replica has no such luxury, with the recreation relying largely on people's memory.

Denis Coutant says the memories of traditional owners will give the project depth. (ABC News: Mitchell Edgar)

"So it does have a depth and a very sensitive meaning to it," Mr Coutant said.

'Tangible surface'

Adding to the challenge, traditional owners do not want steel used in the construction, because it can corrode.

Instead, Mr Browne and his team have taken "texture stamps" directly off Pilbara rocks, including remnants of Juukan, that will be turned into concrete moulds to make sections of the on-site replica.

Imprints of Pilbara rockface are being turned into concrete molds to make an on-site copy of the destroyed Juukan rock shelter. (ABC News: Mitchell Edgar)

"We worked out a way to clone the surface over so the geometry was much, much sharper," he said.

"We want that tangible, tangible surface."

An acrylic casting of Pilbara rock face. (ABC News: Mya Kordic)

The goal is for the Juukan replica to ensure such destruction does not happen again.

"It has to be a legacy that we leave to the PKKP people and to other people in the country, and potentially even in other countries," Mr Coutant said.

"There are First Nations everywhere in the world who have to deal with mining or large-scale projects who are suffering as well from an impact on their country, and impact on their own heritage."

A model of a plan to rebuild a replica of the Juukan rock shelter, destroyed by mining company Rio Tinto in 2020. (ABC News: Mya Kordic)

title: ‘It’s bras and panties’: The Victoria’s Secret show is back
text:
With a cavalcade of bedazzled bras, panties and supermodels with bouncy blowouts, the Victoria’s Secret runway show in New York cemented its return to the fashion calendar. It’s almost as though its cultural cancellation in 2019 never happened. #MeWho?

Performers Missy Elliott, Karol G, TWICE and Madison Beer, top-tier models Gigi and Bella Hadid, Emily Ratajkowski and underwear that would not survive a single spin in a tumble dryer were reminiscent of the show’s cultural peak, when Taylor Swift performed on the runway in 2013 and 2014. That was before the Victoria’s Secret runway show was cancelled in 2019, finally returning last year with Kate Moss, her daughter Lila and Cher.

This was not the place to raise ties between sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and Leslie Wexner, the former head of Victoria’s Secret’s parent company, who stepped down in 2020. Accusations of harassment and misogyny against former chief marketing officer Ed Razek, who controversially told Vogue he did not think “transsexuals” should be included in the show, before stepping down in 2019, were also silenced by the sound of clacking pink heels on the runway.

Gigi Hadid at the 2025 Victoria’s Secret runway show in New York. Credit: Variety via Getty Images

title: AFL trade news LIVE: Candid Curnow opens up on Voss, Blues exit; Dons won’t commit to Merrett as skipper
text:
Sydney recruit Charlie Curnow says he had a great working relationship with Michael Voss, and will remember fondly the four years he played under the Carlton coach.

A day after his move to the Swans was finalised in the closing minutes of trade period, Curnow opened up on his departure from the Blues.

New Swans forward Charlie Curnow in South Melbourne on Thursday. Credit: Eddie Jim

Curnow said that after nine years at Ikon Park, he needed a fresh start but had not spoken to other clubs until the end of the season.

He spoke highly of Voss, and refuted speculation his relationship with the Blues coach had become strained this year.

“Not at all,” Curnow said at his unveiling as Swan at Sydney’s Melbourne office in South Melbourne.

“In the end, it’s a pretty high-pressure environment.

“I think, obviously some things that maybe leaked out there that I would say aren’t true. It’s always a tough environment football and it’s going to be a lot of challenges that come with that. But for me and him, like I don’t see our relationship being affected at all by this.

Loading

“It’s just hard to have a few good conversations with him at the end of the season to if I want to get traded, it’s just you have to do that, you can’t just look and go behind his back and just start putting myself out there.

“I think we’re in a pretty healthy spot and as I said before, like I played some awesome footy under him and I thank him a lot for that.

“Like that was a tough part of my career coming over a knee injury and then trying to play. He dealt with that fantastically.”

Curnow said he would contact Voss again to thank him.

“I played some great footy under Vossy, we had a great relationship,” Curnow said.

“I owe him a lot, I came out of an injury and was able to play three years and four in a row beneath him and play good footy.

“That’s going to be some of my best memories when I look back and have finished footy, playing underneath him.”

title: Brisbane news live: Trio pictured after serious assault in Valley; Cheapest fuel is on the southside
text:
The Crisafulli government has claimed the Cross River Rail project cost has blown out by another $2 billion in the past 10 months – an increase it blamed on the Labor Party.

During ministerial statements in state parliament this morning, Transport Minister Brent Mickelberg – who last December put a $17 billion price tag on the project – said “extensive negotiations with contractors” had resulted in a revised total cost of $19.04 billion.

It was a far cry from the former Labor government’s $5.4 billion cost, but by the LNP government’s own admission the new figure included additional work throughout the train network that had not initially been included in Cross River Rail’s line-item costs.

Transport Minister Brent Mickelberg. Credit: Jamila Filippone

“Our government has also made it clear that contractors would be held to account for their performance,” Mickelberg told parliament.

“That’s why there are now elements of funding conditional on exceptional performance, and contractors meeting major milestones on time. If they don’t deliver, they won’t get paid.”

Brisbane Times has asked Mickelberg’s office for a full rundown of its $19.04 billion estimate. Comment was also sought from Labor.
